subsection_content:
Syphilis causes patients to face many health problems. Therefore, when detecting that you are infected with this spirochete, doctors will proceed:
Drug treatment
In the early stages, syphilis is easily cured with medication. Therefore, one of the top choices of doctors is to give patients Penicillin, an antibiotic that can kill the bacteria that cause syphilis and is often effective in most stages. If you are allergic to Penicillin, your doctor may recommend a different antibiotic or Penicillin desensitization.
If diagnosed with primary, secondary or early latent syphilis (less than one year), the recommended treatment is a single injection of Penicillin. For people who have had syphilis for more than a year, the doctor may give an additional dose. Penicillin is also the only recommended treatment for pregnant women with syphilis.
On the first day of treatment, patients may experience a Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, with symptoms including fever, chills, nausea, aches and pains and headaches. This reaction usually does not last more than a day.
Monitor treatment
After you are treated for syphilis with medication, your doctor will ask the patient to:
Periodic check-ups and blood tests to ensure that the person is responding to the usual dosage of Penicillin. Specific monitoring depends on the stage of syphilis diagnosed.; Avoid having sex with a new partner until treatment is complete and blood tests show the infection is cured.; Notify sexual partners so they can be examined and treated if necessary; Test to see if you are infected with the HIV virus.
